metadata.title: The Links Between Industrial, Community, and Ecological Sustainability: A Forestry Case Study

relevance.topic: Industrial, Community, and Ecological Sustainability in Forestry
relevance.relevance: The study examines the impact of technological change on labor displacement in the sawmilling industry, highlighting the replacement of labor by capital and its effects on community and ecological sustainability.

design.sample_characteristics: Sawmill workers in British Columbia, Canada, from 1950 to 1985.

dependent_variables.displaced: 40% of the sawmill workforce was eliminated during the early 1980s recession.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: 17% of workers were unemployed by 1985, and those who found jobs outside the industry earned 33% less.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Workers who found jobs outside the industry earned 33% less in 1985 than their sawmill jobs had paid in 1978.

key_themes: Impact of technological change on labor displacement
text_fragments: The recession of the early 1980s eliminated over 40% of the sawmill workforce and stimulated increased replacement of labor by capital.
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the impact of technological change on sawmill workers, highlighting the reduction in workforce and the increased ecological footprint due to capital replacement.

historical_context.institutional_context: Policies encouraging or forcing early retirement during economic downturns.

outcomes.main_findings: The study found that technological changes in the sawmilling industry led to significant labor displacement, with a 40% reduction in workforce and increased ecological footprint.
outcomes.conclusions: Technological advancements increased productivity but led to job losses and reduced community and ecological sustainability.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that job losses and reduced incomes have long-term impacts on community viability and ecological sustainability.
